awd_abstract_narration:
The proposal seeks to support participation of US-based mathematicians, especially those in the early stages of career, at the international conference "Finite Dimensional Integrable Systems 2023, to be held at the University of Antwerp, Belgium, on August 7-11, 2023. The conference will bring together leading experts, early-career researchers, and graduate students in this far-reaching and fast-growing area of research. The conference web site is  
https://www.uantwerpen.be/nl/personeel/sonja-hohloch/private-webpage/conference-workshop/fdis2023/

The conference focuses on recent progress in the study of integrable systems with a finite number of degrees of freedom, a subfield of the theory of completely integrable systems that grew out of the now classical work of Lagrange, Jacobi, Kovalevskaya, Noether, Poincare, and others. In the second half of 20th century, KAM theory, due to Kolmogorov, Arnold and Moser, revealed new perspectives on integrability problems, stimulating progress in the area and the development of powerful techniques that bridge mathematics and physics.  These have resulted in the discovery of new kinds of integrable systems, broader applications in physics and geometry, and solutions to long-standing open questions. The conference will survey recent progress in the field, present new directions of research and applications, and foster collaborations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The conference FDIS 2023 was the 7th edition in the series of international conferences on Finite Dimensional Integrable Systems in Geometry and Mathematical Physics (FDIS 2023). It took place at the University of Antwerpen on August 7-11, 2023.

The program of the conference featured 14 plenary and 19 contributed talks along with a poster session. The web site of the conference is maintained by the local organizer, professor Sonja Hohloch; it contains downloadable slides of many talks. The schedule was designed to provide ample time for informal discussions and other research-related activities. The poster session provided an opportunity to the junior participants (graduate students, postdocs) to present their research.

Six talks were given by US-based mathematicians who were partially supported by this grant. 

Intellectual merit was in bringing together leading experts in the field of finite dimensional completely integrable systems, along with researchers in the early stage of career and graduate students, in order to survey recent progress in this area, to present open problems, to outline new directions of research, to find new applications, and to foster new collaborations.

Broader impacts were  in attracting new talent to research in the field of finite dimensional completely integrable systems, and in finding new ap- plications of the methods and techniques of this theory in mathematics and in exact sciences.
